prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As detailed in the Scientific Justification, our goal is to reach a continuum sensitivity at 345GHz of 0.2mJy (4 sigma). At the requested angular resolution, ~0.4arcsec, or 60-80AU at the distance of our targets, we do not expect to significantly resolve the emission and we require an rms sensitivity of 0.05 mJy/beam. We have selected a correlator setup with three wide bands for continuum sensitivity and a smaller band to cover the co(3-2) line (the resulting loss of bandwidth is less than 20%, as compared to a continuum-only setup). We do expect to reach the goal noise level in ~20 minutes on source, depending on the target elevation.

This is mainly a continuum detection experiment. Nonetheless, we will sacrify a moderate amount of bandwidth (~20%) to serendipitously search for CO(3-2) emission in the target sources. Should the line emission be unexpectedly bright, we also use for une of the broad spectral windows (which covers the 13CO(3-2) line, a moderately good spectral resolution (without sacrifying the bandwidth).

We do not expect to image the targets, hence have no special requirements in the (u,v) coverage. The observations are best done with 0.4 arcsec resolution, which offer the possibility of showing moderately extended emission if the disks turn out to be brighter than expected. The integration time is defined by our sensitivity goal, not by (u,v) coverage constraints.

As detailed in the Scientific Justification, our goal is to reach a continuum sensitivity at 345GHz of 0.2mJy (4 sigma). We do expect to reach the goal noise level in ~20 minutes on source, depending on the target elevation.

This is mainly a continuum detection experiment. Nonetheless, we will sacrify a moderate amount of bandwidth (~20%) to serendipitously search for CO(3-2) emission in the target sources. Should the line emission be unexpectedly bright, we also use for une of the broad spectral windows (which covers the 13CO(3-2) line, a moderately good spectral resolution (without sacrifying the bandwidth).

We do not expect to image the targets, hence have no special requirements in the (u,v) coverage. The observations are best done with 0.4 arcsec resolution, which offer the possibility of showing moderately extended emission if the disks turn out to be brighter than expected. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ClassIII_Tau_2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Class III objects in Taurus HBC_388

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As detailed in the Scientific Justification, our goal is to reach a continuum sensitivity at 345GHz of 0.2mJy (4 sigma). At the requested angular resolution, ~0.4arcsec, or 60-80AU at the distance of our targets, we do not expect to significantly resolve the emission and we require an rms sensitivity of 0.05 mJy/beam. We have selected a correlator setup with three wide bands for continuum sensitivity and a smaller band to cover the co(3-2) line (the resulting loss of bandwidth is less than 20%, as compared to a continuum-only setup). We do expect to reach the goal noise level in ~20 minutes on source, depending on the target elevation.

This is mainly a continuum detection experiment. Nonetheless, we will sacrify a moderate amount of bandwidth (~20%) to serendipitously search for CO(3-2) emission in the target sources. Should the line emission be unexpectedly bright, we also use for une of the broad spectral windows (which covers the 13CO(3-2) line, a moderately good spectral resolution (without sacrifying the bandwidth).

We do not expect to image the targets, hence have no special requirements in the (u,v) coverage. The observations are best done with 0.4 arcsec resolution, which offer the possibility of showing moderately extended emission if the disks turn out to be brighter than expected. The integration time is defined by our sensitivity goal, not by (u,v) coverage constraints.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Single solar mass stars are all expected to form with a relatively massive circumstellar disk as a result of angular momentum conservation during collapse. Planetary systems are formed in these disks in the majority of systems, as indicated by exoplanets searches. Typical lifetimes of disks (~3 Myr) set the typical timescale for planet formation, however, even in the youngest star forming regions, the fraction of stars without a massive disk is significant. It is thus possible that, in some cases, planet formation and outer disk photoevaporation occur on much faster timescales (<1Myr) that currently envisaged. We propose to search for young debris disks, the remnants of this early planet formation process, in a sample of single diskless solar-mass young stars in the Ophiuchus and Taurus star forming regions. Our observations are designed to produce stringent limits on the possible existence of these debris disks and will be able to conclusively prove or disprove the hypothesis of early planet formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
